title: 105_hr3314
content: The "Fathers Count Act of 1998" establishes grants to states to encourage fathers to become better parents. States must submit a plan to the Secretary outlining how they will review and administer funds provided under this Act. The Secretary will grant funds to states that comply with the Fathers Count Act of 1998, based on their population in relation to the total U.S. population, starting from fiscal year 2000. The specified amounts for funding under the Fathers Count Act of 1998 are $200,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $300,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $400,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2004. The specified amounts for funding under the Fathers Count Act of 1998 are outlined for fiscal years 2000 to 2004. SEC. 443 details the use of funds. The Fathers Count Act of 1998 outlines grant usage for states, emphasizing projects to promote marriage and better parenting by fathers. Funds must be allocated to nongovernmental organizations. The Fathers Count Act of 1998 requires states to allocate grant funds to nongovernmental organizations. States must ensure that at least 80 percent of the funds are used to provide services for fathers with incomes below the state or local average. Any remaining funds must be returned to the Secretary if not spent by the end of the next fiscal year. The Fathers Count Act of 1998 mandates states to allocate grant funds to NGOs, with a focus on serving low-income fathers. States can use welfare-to-work and Title XX funds for activities under this Act, coordinating with the TANF program. States must administer welfare-to-work funds through the appropriate agency and coordinate their programs funded under this Act with those funded under part A. States are responsible for disbursing funds in accordance with the Act. The Fathers Count Act of 1998 requires states to allocate grant funds to NGOs serving low-income fathers. States can use welfare-to-work and Title XX funds for activities under this Act, coordinating with the TANF program. Funds received by a state must be appropriated by the state legislature and disbursed by the Governor in accordance with the Act. Services can also be provided by charitable, religious, or private organizations. States have the option to administer services through contracts with charitable, religious, or private organizations and provide beneficiaries with redeemable certificates or vouchers. This allows religious organizations to participate without compromising their religious character or the freedom of beneficiaries. Religious organizations can participate in programs under this part on the same basis as other private organizations, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause of the United States Constitution. Discrimination based on religious character is prohibited for organizations providing assistance or accepting vouchers. Religious organizations participating in programs under this part must maintain independence from government control over their religious beliefs and practices. They are not required to change their internal governance or remove religious symbols to be eligible for assistance. The rights of beneficiaries of assistance include the option to receive aid from an alternative provider if they object to the religious character of the organization providing the assistance. The state must ensure the alternative provider is accessible and provides assistance of equal value. An individual receiving assistance under a program must not be discriminated against based on religion. A religious organization's employment practices exemption under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is not affected by participation in these programs. Fiscal accountability is required for funds received under this part. Any religious organization contracting to provide assistance funded under this program must adhere to auditing regulations. If the organization segregates federal funds into separate accounts, only the financial assistance provided with those funds will be audited. Parties can enforce their rights through civil action in State court for violations. No funds can be used for certain purposes. No funds provided for services under this program can be used for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. State laws restricting state funds in religious organizations are not preempted. "SEC. 447. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS." The Secretary can reduce payments to a State if funds are misused, with a limit of 10 percent reduction. Any unrecovered penalties can be carried forward to the next fiscal year. The Secretary can reduce State payments by up to 10% for misuse of funds, with any remaining penalties carried over to the next fiscal year. Adverse decisions can be appealed under Section 410 in the same manner as under part A. "SEC. 448. RESEARCH, EVALUATIONS, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE." The Secretary conducts research on State programs funded under this part, evaluates grant usage annually, and provides technical assistance to States. Reports on evaluations are submitted to Congress every two fiscal years. The Secretary provides technical assistance to States for disseminating information about successful programs. Authorization of appropriations is limited to $10,000,000 for research and evaluations each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004. The Secretary has limited reprogramming authority to use up to 20% of appropriated funds during a fiscal year. The Secretary can allocate up to 20% of appropriated funds for a specific purpose under subsection (d) in a fiscal year. In this part, "fiscal year" is defined as a 12-month period ending on September 30 of a calendar year, and "State" is defined as the 50 States of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, and American Samoa.
